intro: Astragalus pachyacanthus var. lasiocladus, commonly known as the hairy thorned milkvetch, is a perennial legume native to the arid and semi-arid regions of western North America. It is characterized by its spiny stems and small, yellowish to brownish flowers that bloom in late spring. The plant has compound leaves with small, oval-shaped leaflets and is often found in rocky or sandy soils. It is adapted to drought conditions and can thrive in poor soil environments. This species is also valued for its ecological role in stabilizing soil and providing forage for wildlife.
